name: Table
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table
description:
Table

A named resource representing a BigQuery table that holds zero or more records. Every table is defined by a schema that may contain nested and repeated fields.

The Table class can also represent a view, which is a virtual table defined by a SQL query. BigQuery’s views are logical views, not materialized views, which means that the query that defines the view is re-executed every time the view is queried. Queries are billed according to the total amount of data in all table fields referenced directly or indirectly by the top-level query. (See #view?, #query, #query=, and Dataset#create_view.)

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |schema|
  schema.string "first_name", mode: :required
  schema.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |nested_schema|
    nested_schema.string "place", mode: :required
    nested_schema.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

row = {
  "first_name" => "Alice",
  "cities_lived" => [
    {
      "place" => "Seattle",
      "number_of_years" => 5
    },
    {
      "place" => "Stockholm",
      "number_of_years" => 6
    }
  ]
}
table.insert row

examples.caption: Creating a BigQuery view:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
view = dataset.create_view "my_view",
         "SELECT name, age FROM `my_project.my_dataset.my_table`"
view.view? # true

methods.name: table_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#table_id
methods.description: A unique ID for this table.

returns.description:
The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers
(0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum length is 1,024 characters.

methods.name: dataset_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#dataset_id
methods.description: The ID of the Dataset containing this table.

returns.description:
The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers
(0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum length is 1,024 characters.

methods.name: project_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#project_id
methods.description: The ID of the Project containing this table.

returns.description: The project ID.

methods.name: time_partitioning?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#time_partitioning?
methods.description: Checks if the table is time-partitioned. See Partitioned Tables.

returns.description: true when the table is time-partitioned, or false otherwise, if the object is a resource (see #resource?); nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: time_partitioning_type
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#time_partitioning_type
methods.description: The period for which the table is partitioned, if any. See Partitioned Tables.

returns.description: The partition type. Currently the only supported value is “DAY”, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: time_partitioning_type=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#time_partitioning_type=
methods.description:
Sets the partitioning for the table. See Partitioned Tables.

You can only set partitioning when creating a table as in the example below. BigQuery does not allow you to change partitioning on an existing table.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |table|
  table.time_partitioning_type = "DAY"
end

params.name: type
params.description:
The partition type. Currently the only
supported value is “DAY”.

methods.name: time_partitioning_expiration
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#time_partitioning_expiration
methods.description: The expiration for the table partitions, if any, in seconds. See Partitioned Tables.

returns.description: The expiration time, in seconds, for data in partitions, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: time_partitioning_expiration=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#time_partitioning_expiration=
methods.description:
Sets the partition expiration for the table. See Partitioned Tables. The table must also be partitioned.

See Table#time_partitioning_type=.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |table|
  table.time_partitioning_type = "DAY"
  table.time_partitioning_expiration = 86_400
end

params.name: expiration
params.description:
An expiration time, in seconds,
for data in partitions.

methods.name: id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#id
methods.description: The combined Project ID, Dataset ID, and Table ID for this table, in the format specified by the Legacy SQL Query Reference: project_name:datasetId.tableId. To use this value in queries see #query_id.

returns.description: The combined ID, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: query_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query_id
methods.description: The value returned by #id, wrapped in square brackets if the Project ID contains dashes, as specified by the Query Reference. Useful in queries.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = bigquery.query "SELECT first_name FROM #{table.query_id}"

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is false.

returns.description:
The appropriate table ID for use in queries,
depending on SQL type.

methods.name: name
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#name
methods.description: The name of the table.

returns.description: The friendly name, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: name=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#name=
methods.description:
Updates the name of the table.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

params.name: new_name
params.description: The new friendly name.

methods.name: etag
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#etag
methods.description: The ETag hash of the table.

returns.description: The ETag hash, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: api_url
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#api_url
methods.description: A URL that can be used to access the table using the REST API.

returns.description: A REST URL for the resource, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: description
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#description
methods.description: A user-friendly description of the table.

returns.description: The description, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: description=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#description=
methods.description:
Updates the user-friendly description of the table.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

params.name: new_description
params.description: The new user-friendly description.

methods.name: bytes_count
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#bytes_count
methods.description: The number of bytes in the table.

returns.description: The count of bytes in the table, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: rows_count
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#rows_count
methods.description: The number of rows in the table.

returns.description: The count of rows in the table, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: created_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#created_at
methods.description: The time when this table was created.

returns.description: The creation time, or nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: expires_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#expires_at
methods.description: The time when this table expires. If not present, the table will persist indefinitely. Expired tables will be deleted and their storage reclaimed.

returns.description: The expiration time, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: modified_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#modified_at
methods.description: The date when this table was last modified.

returns.description: The last modified time, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: table?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#table?
methods.description: Checks if the table’s type is “TABLE”.

returns.description: true when the type is TABLE, false otherwise, if the object is a resource (see #resource?); nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: view?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#view?
methods.description: Checks if the table’s type is “VIEW”, indicating that the table represents a BigQuery view. See Dataset#create_view.

returns.description: true when the type is VIEW, false otherwise, if the object is a resource (see #resource?); nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: external?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#external?
methods.description: Checks if the table’s type is “EXTERNAL”, indicating that the table represents an External Data Source. See #external? and External::DataSource.

returns.description: true when the type is EXTERNAL, false otherwise, if the object is a resource (see #resource?); nil if the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: location
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#location
methods.description: The geographic location where the table should reside. Possible values include EU and US. The default value is US.

returns.description: The location code.

methods.name: labels
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#labels
methods.description:
A hash of user-provided labels associated with this table. Labels are used to organize and group tables. See Using Labels.

The returned hash is frozen and changes are not allowed. Use #labels= to replace the entire hash.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

labels = table.labels
labels["department"] #=> "shipping"

returns.description: A hash containing key/value pairs.

methods.name: labels=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#labels=
methods.description:
Updates the hash of user-provided labels associated with this table. Labels are used to organize and group tables. See Using Labels.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.labels = { "department" => "shipping" }

params.name: labels
params.description:
A hash containing key/value pairs.

  • Label keys and values can be no longer than 63 characters.
  • Label keys and values can contain only lowercase letters, numbers, underscores, hyphens, and international characters.
  • Label keys and values cannot exceed 128 bytes in size.
  • Label keys must begin with a letter.
  • Label keys must be unique within a table.

methods.name: schema
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#schema
methods.description:
Returns the table’s schema. If the table is not a view (See #view?), this method can also be used to set, replace, or add to the schema by passing a block. See Schema for available methods.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table"

table.schema do |schema|
  schema.string "first_name", mode: :required
  schema.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |nested_schema|
    nested_schema.string "place", mode: :required
    nested_schema.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

params.name: replace
params.description: Whether to replace the existing schema with the new schema. If true, the fields will replace the existing schema. If false, the fields will be added to the existing schema. When a table already contains data, schema changes must be additive. Thus, the default value is false.

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting the schema

params.name: yield.schema
params.description: the object accepting the schema

returns.description: A frozen schema object.

methods.name: fields
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#fields
methods.description: The fields of the table, obtained from its schema.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.fields.each do |field|
  puts field.name
end

returns.description: An array of field objects.

methods.name: headers
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#headers
methods.description: The names of the columns in the table, obtained from its schema.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.headers.each do |header|
  puts header
end

returns.description: An array of column names.

methods.name: external
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#external
methods.description:
The External::DataSource (or subclass) object that represents the external data source that the table represents. Data can be queried the table, even though the data is not stored in BigQuery. Instead of loading or streaming the data, this object references the external data source.

Present only if the table represents an External Data Source. See #external? and External::DataSource.

returns.description:
The external data source.

@!group Attributes

methods.name: external=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#external=
methods.description:
Set the External::DataSource (or subclass) object that represents the external data source that the table represents. Data can be queried the table, even though the data is not stored in BigQuery. Instead of loading or streaming the data, this object references the external data source.

Use only if the table represents an External Data Source. See #external? and External::DataSource.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the update to comply with ETag-based optimistic concurrency control.

params.name: external
params.description: An external data source.

methods.name: buffer_bytes
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#buffer_bytes
methods.description: A lower-bound estimate of the number of bytes currently in this table’s streaming buffer, if one is present. This field will be absent if the table is not being streamed to or if there is no data in the streaming buffer.

returns.description: The estimated number of bytes in the buffer, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: buffer_rows
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#buffer_rows
methods.description: A lower-bound estimate of the number of rows currently in this table’s streaming buffer, if one is present. This field will be absent if the table is not being streamed to or if there is no data in the streaming buffer.

returns.description: The estimated number of rows in the buffer, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: buffer_oldest_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#buffer_oldest_at
methods.description: The time of the oldest entry currently in this table’s streaming buffer, if one is present. This field will be absent if the table is not being streamed to or if there is no data in the streaming buffer.

returns.description: The oldest entry time, or nil if not present or the object is a reference (see #reference?).

methods.name: query
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query
methods.description: The query that executes each time the view is loaded.

returns.description: The query that defines the view.

methods.name: query=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query=
methods.description:
Updates the query that executes each time the view is loaded.

This sets the query using standard SQL. To specify legacy SQL or to use user-defined function resources use (#set_query) instead.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
view = dataset.table "my_view"

view.query = "SELECT first_name FROM " \
               "`my_project.my_dataset.my_table`"

params.name: new_query
params.description: The query that defines the view.

methods.name: set_query
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#set_query
methods.description: Updates the query that executes each time the view is loaded. Allows setting of standard vs. legacy SQL and user-defined function resources.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
view = dataset.table "my_view"

view.set_query "SELECT first_name FROM " \
                 "`my_project.my_dataset.my_table`",
               standard_sql: true

params.name: query
params.description: The query that defines the view.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is false.

params.name: udfs
params.description: User-defined function resources used in the query. May be either a code resource to load from a Google Cloud Storage URI (gs://bucket/path), or an inline resource that contains code for a user-defined function (UDF). Providing an inline code resource is equivalent to providing a URI for a file containing the same code. See User-Defined Functions.

methods.name: query_legacy_sql?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query_legacy_sql?
methods.description: Checks if the view’s query is using legacy sql.

returns.description: true when legacy sql is used, false otherwise.

methods.name: query_standard_sql?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query_standard_sql?
methods.description: Checks if the view’s query is using standard sql.

returns.description: true when standard sql is used, false otherwise.

methods.name: query_udfs
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#query_udfs
methods.description: The user-defined function resources used in the view’s query. May be either a code resource to load from a Google Cloud Storage URI (gs://bucket/path), or an inline resource that contains code for a user-defined function (UDF). Providing an inline code resource is equivalent to providing a URI for a file containing the same code. See User-Defined Functions.

returns.description:
An array containing Google Cloud Storage URIs
and/or inline source code.

methods.name: data
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#data
methods.description:
Retrieves data from the table.

If the table is not a full resource representation (see #resource_full?), the full representation will be retrieved before the data retrieval.

examples.caption: Paginate rows of data: (See Data#next)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = table.data
data.each do |row|
  puts row[:first_name]
end
if data.next?
  more_data = data.next if data.next?
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all rows of data: (See Data#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

data = table.data
data.all do |row|
  puts row[:first_name]
end

params.name: token
params.description:
Page token, returned by a previous call,
identifying the result set.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of results to return.

params.name: start
params.description: Zero-based index of the starting row to read.

methods.name: copy_job
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#copy_job
methods.description: Copies the data from the table to another table using an asynchronous method. In this method, a CopyJob is immediately returned. The caller may poll the service by repeatedly calling Job#reload! and Job#done? to detect when the job is done, or simply block until the job is done by calling #Job#wait_until_done!. See also #copy.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"
destination_table = dataset.table "my_destination_table"

copy_job = table.copy_job destination_table

examples.caption: Passing a string identifier for the destination table:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

copy_job = table.copy_job "other-project:other_dataset.other_table"

params.name: destination_table
params.description: The destination for the copied data. This can also be a string identifier as specified by the Query Reference: project_name:datasetId.tableId. This is useful for referencing tables in other projects and datasets.

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables. The default value is needed.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the destination table. The default value is empty.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the destination table already contains data.

params.name: job_id
params.description:
A user-defined ID for the copy job. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

See Generating a job ID.

params.name: prefix
params.description: A string, usually human-readable, that will be prepended to a generated value to produce a unique job ID. For example, the prefix daily_import_job_ can be given to generate a job ID such as daily_import_job_12vEDtMQ0mbp1Mo5Z7mzAFQJZazh. The prefix must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length of the entire ID is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

params.name: labels
params.description:
A hash of user-provided labels associated with
the job. You can use these to organize and group your jobs. Label
keys and values can be no longer than 63 characters, can only
contain lowercase letters, numeric characters, underscores and
dashes. International characters are allowed. Label values are
optional. Label keys must start with a letter and each label in the
list must have a different key.

methods.name: copy
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#copy
methods.description: Copies the data from the table to another table using a synchronous method that blocks for a response. Timeouts and transient errors are generally handled as needed to complete the job. See also #copy_job.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"
destination_table = dataset.table "my_destination_table"

table.copy destination_table

examples.caption: Passing a string identifier for the destination table:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.copy "other-project:other_dataset.other_table"

params.name: destination_table
params.description: The destination for the copied data. This can also be a string identifier as specified by the Query Reference: project_name:datasetId.tableId. This is useful for referencing tables in other projects and datasets.

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables. The default value is needed.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the destination table. The default value is empty.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the destination table already contains data.

returns.description: Returns true if the copy operation succeeded.

methods.name: extract_job
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#extract_job
methods.description: Extracts the data from the table to a Google Cloud Storage file using an asynchronous method. In this method, an ExtractJob is immediately returned. The caller may poll the service by repeatedly calling Job#reload! and Job#done? to detect when the job is done, or simply block until the job is done by calling #Job#wait_until_done!. See also #extract.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

extract_job = table.extract_job "gs://my-bucket/file-name.json",
                            format: "json"

params.name: extract_url
params.description:
The Google Storage file or file URI pattern(s) to which
BigQuery should extract the table data.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro

params.name: compression
params.description: The compression type to use for exported files. Possible values include GZIP and NONE. The default value is NONE.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Delimiter to use between fields in the exported data. Default is ,.

params.name: header
params.description: Whether to print out a header row in the results. Default is true.

params.name: job_id
params.description:
A user-defined ID for the extract job. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

See Generating a job ID.

params.name: prefix
params.description: A string, usually human-readable, that will be prepended to a generated value to produce a unique job ID. For example, the prefix daily_import_job_ can be given to generate a job ID such as daily_import_job_12vEDtMQ0mbp1Mo5Z7mzAFQJZazh. The prefix must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length of the entire ID is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

params.name: labels
params.description:
A hash of user-provided labels associated with
the job. You can use these to organize and group your jobs. Label
keys and values can be no longer than 63 characters, can only
contain lowercase letters, numeric characters, underscores and
dashes. International characters are allowed. Label values are
optional. Label keys must start with a letter and each label in the
list must have a different key.

methods.name: extract
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#extract
methods.description: Extracts the data from the table to a Google Cloud Storage file using a synchronous method that blocks for a response. Timeouts and transient errors are generally handled as needed to complete the job. See also #extract_job.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.extract "gs://my-bucket/file-name.json", format: "json"

params.name: extract_url
params.description:
The Google Storage file or file URI pattern(s) to which
BigQuery should extract the table data.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro

params.name: compression
params.description: The compression type to use for exported files. Possible values include GZIP and NONE. The default value is NONE.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Delimiter to use between fields in the exported data. Default is ,.

params.name: header
params.description: Whether to print out a header row in the results. Default is true.

returns.description: Returns true if the extract operation succeeded.

methods.name: load_job
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#load_job
methods.description: Loads data into the table. You can pass a google-cloud storage file path or a google-cloud storage file instance. Or, you can upload a file directly. See Loading Data with a POST Request.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

load_job = table.load_job "gs://my-bucket/file-name.csv"

examples.caption: Pass a google-cloud-storage File instance:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"
require "google/cloud/storage"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

storage = Google::Cloud::Storage.new
bucket = storage.bucket "my-bucket"
file = bucket.file "file-name.csv"
load_job = table.load_job file

examples.caption: Upload a file directly:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

file = File.open "my_data.csv"
load_job = table.load_job file

params.name: file
params.description:
A file or the
URI of a Google Cloud Storage file containing data to load into the
table.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro
  • datastore_backup - Cloud Datastore backup

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables. The default value is needed.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the table. The default value is append.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the table already contains data.

params.name: projection_fields
params.description: If the format option is set to datastore_backup, indicates which entity properties to load from a Cloud Datastore backup. Property names are case sensitive and must be top-level properties. If not set, BigQuery loads all properties. If any named property isn’t found in the Cloud Datastore backup, an invalid error is returned.

params.name: jagged_rows
params.description: Accept rows that are missing trailing optional columns. The missing values are treated as nulls. If false, records with missing trailing columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false. Only applicable to CSV, ignored for other formats.

params.name: quoted_newlines
params.description: Indicates if BigQuery should allow quoted data sections that contain newline characters in a CSV file. The default value is false.

params.name: autodetect
params.description: Indicates if BigQuery should automatically infer the options and schema for CSV and JSON sources. The default value is false.

params.name: encoding
params.description: The character encoding of the data. The supported values are UTF-8 or ISO-8859-1. The default value is UTF-8.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Specifices the separator for fields in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. Default is ,.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Indicates if BigQuery should allow extra values that are not represented in the table schema. If true, the extra values are ignored. If false, records with extra columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false.

The format property determines what BigQuery treats as an extra value:

  • CSV: Trailing columns
  • JSON: Named values that don’t match any column names

params.name: max_bad_records
params.description: The maximum number of bad records that BigQuery can ignore when running the job. If the number of bad records exceeds this value, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is 0, which requires that all records are valid.

params.name: null_marker
params.description: Specifies a string that represents a null value in a CSV file. For example, if you specify \N, BigQuery interprets \N as a null value when loading a CSV file. The default value is the empty string. If you set this property to a custom value, BigQuery throws an error if an empty string is present for all data types except for STRING and BYTE. For STRING and BYTE columns, BigQuery interprets the empty string as an empty value.

params.name: quote
params.description: The value that is used to quote data sections in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. The default value is a double-quote ". If your data does not contain quoted sections, set the property value to an empty string. If your data contains quoted newline characters, you must also set the allowQuotedNewlines property to true.

params.name: skip_leading
params.description: The number of rows at the top of a CSV file that BigQuery will skip when loading the data. The default value is 0. This property is useful if you have header rows in the file that should be skipped.

params.name: job_id
params.description:
A user-defined ID for the load job. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

See Generating a job ID.

params.name: prefix
params.description: A string, usually human-readable, that will be prepended to a generated value to produce a unique job ID. For example, the prefix daily_import_job_ can be given to generate a job ID such as daily_import_job_12vEDtMQ0mbp1Mo5Z7mzAFQJZazh. The prefix must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), underscores (_), or dashes (-). The maximum length of the entire ID is 1,024 characters. If job_id is provided, then prefix will not be used.

params.name: labels
params.description:
A hash of user-provided labels associated with
the job. You can use these to organize and group your jobs. Label
keys and values can be no longer than 63 characters, can only
contain lowercase letters, numeric characters, underscores and
dashes. International characters are allowed. Label values are
optional. Label keys must start with a letter and each label in the
list must have a different key.

methods.name: load
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#load
methods.description: Loads data into the table. You can pass a google-cloud storage file path or a google-cloud storage file instance. Or, you can upload a file directly. See Loading Data with a POST Request.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

load_job = table.load_job "gs://my-bucket/file-name.csv"

examples.caption: Pass a google-cloud-storage File instance:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"
require "google/cloud/storage"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

storage = Google::Cloud::Storage.new
bucket = storage.bucket "my-bucket"
file = bucket.file "file-name.csv"
load_job = table.load_job file

examples.caption: Upload a file directly:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

file = File.open "my_data.csv"
load_job = table.load_job file

params.name: file
params.description:
A file or the
URI of a Google Cloud Storage file containing data to load into the
table.

params.name: format
params.description:
The exported file format. The default value is csv.

The following values are supported:

  • csv - CSV
  • json - Newline-delimited JSON
  • avro - Avro
  • datastore_backup - Cloud Datastore backup

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables. The default value is needed.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies how to handle data already present in the table. The default value is append.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - An error will be returned if the table already contains data.

params.name: projection_fields
params.description: If the format option is set to datastore_backup, indicates which entity properties to load from a Cloud Datastore backup. Property names are case sensitive and must be top-level properties. If not set, BigQuery loads all properties. If any named property isn’t found in the Cloud Datastore backup, an invalid error is returned.

params.name: jagged_rows
params.description: Accept rows that are missing trailing optional columns. The missing values are treated as nulls. If false, records with missing trailing columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false. Only applicable to CSV, ignored for other formats.

params.name: quoted_newlines
params.description: Indicates if BigQuery should allow quoted data sections that contain newline characters in a CSV file. The default value is false.

params.name: autodetect
params.description: Indicates if BigQuery should automatically infer the options and schema for CSV and JSON sources. The default value is false.

params.name: encoding
params.description: The character encoding of the data. The supported values are UTF-8 or ISO-8859-1. The default value is UTF-8.

params.name: delimiter
params.description: Specifices the separator for fields in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. Default is ,.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Indicates if BigQuery should allow extra values that are not represented in the table schema. If true, the extra values are ignored. If false, records with extra columns are treated as bad records, and if there are too many bad records, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is false.

The format property determines what BigQuery treats as an extra value:

  • CSV: Trailing columns
  • JSON: Named values that don’t match any column names

params.name: max_bad_records
params.description: The maximum number of bad records that BigQuery can ignore when running the job. If the number of bad records exceeds this value, an invalid error is returned in the job result. The default value is 0, which requires that all records are valid.

params.name: null_marker
params.description: Specifies a string that represents a null value in a CSV file. For example, if you specify \N, BigQuery interprets \N as a null value when loading a CSV file. The default value is the empty string. If you set this property to a custom value, BigQuery throws an error if an empty string is present for all data types except for STRING and BYTE. For STRING and BYTE columns, BigQuery interprets the empty string as an empty value.

params.name: quote
params.description: The value that is used to quote data sections in a CSV file. BigQuery converts the string to ISO-8859-1 encoding, and then uses the first byte of the encoded string to split the data in its raw, binary state. The default value is a double-quote ". If your data does not contain quoted sections, set the property value to an empty string. If your data contains quoted newline characters, you must also set the allowQuotedNewlines property to true.

params.name: skip_leading
params.description: The number of rows at the top of a CSV file that BigQuery will skip when loading the data. The default value is 0. This property is useful if you have header rows in the file that should be skipped.

methods.name: insert
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#insert
methods.description: Inserts data into the table for near-immediate querying, without the need to complete a load operation before the data can appear in query results.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

rows = [
  { "first_name" => "Alice", "age" => 21 },
  { "first_name" => "Bob", "age" => 22 }
]
table.insert rows

examples.caption: Avoid retrieving the dataset and table with skip_lookup:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset", skip_lookup: true
table = dataset.table "my_table", skip_lookup: true

rows = [
  { "first_name" => "Alice", "age" => 21 },
  { "first_name" => "Bob", "age" => 22 }
]
table.insert rows

params.name: rows
params.description:
A hash object or array of hash objects
containing the data. Required.

params.name: skip_invalid
params.description: Insert all valid rows of a request, even if invalid rows exist. The default value is false, which causes the entire request to fail if any invalid rows exist.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Accept rows that contain values that
do not match the schema. The unknown values are ignored. Default is
false, which treats unknown values as errors.

methods.name: insert_async
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#insert_async
methods.description: Create an asynchronous inserter object used to insert rows in batches.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"
inserter = table.insert_async do |result|
  if result.error?
    log_error result.error
  else
    log_insert "inserted #{result.insert_count} rows " \
      "with #{result.error_count} errors"
  end
end

rows = [
  { "first_name" => "Alice", "age" => 21 },
  { "first_name" => "Bob", "age" => 22 }
]
inserter.insert rows

inserter.stop.wait!

params.name: skip_invalid
params.description: Insert all valid rows of a request, even if invalid rows exist. The default value is false, which causes the entire request to fail if any invalid rows exist.

params.name: ignore_unknown
params.description:
Accept rows that contain values that
do not match the schema. The unknown values are ignored. Default is
false, which treats unknown values as errors.

params.name: max_rows
params.description:
The maximum number of rows to be collected
before the batch is published. Default is 500.

params.name: yield
params.description: the callback for when a batch of rows is inserted

params.name: yield.result
params.description:
the result of the
asynchronous insert

returns.description: Returns inserter object.

methods.name: delete
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#delete
methods.description: Permanently deletes the table.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.delete

returns.description: Returns true if the table was deleted.

methods.name: reload!
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#reload!
methods.description: Reloads the table with current data from the BigQuery service.

examples.caption: Skip retrieving the table from the service, then load it:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table", skip_lookup: true

table.reload!

returns.description:
Returns the reloaded
table.

methods.name: exists?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#exists?
methods.description: Determines whether the table exists in the BigQuery service. The result is cached locally.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table", skip_lookup: true
table.exists? # true

returns.description: true when the table exists in the BigQuery service, false otherwise.

methods.name: reference?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#reference?
methods.description: Whether the table was created without retrieving the resource representation from the BigQuery service.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table", skip_lookup: true

table.reference? # true
table.reload!
table.reference? # false

returns.description: true when the table is just a local reference object, false otherwise.

methods.name: resource?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#resource?
methods.description: Whether the table was created with a resource representation from the BigQuery service.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table", skip_lookup: true

table.resource? # false
table.reload!
table.resource? # true

returns.description: true when the table was created with a resource representation, false otherwise.

methods.name: resource_partial?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#resource_partial?
methods.description: Whether the table was created with a partial resource representation from the BigQuery service by retrieval through Dataset#tables. See Tables: list response for the contents of the partial representation. Accessing any attribute outside of the partial representation will result in loading the full representation.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.tables.first

table.resource_partial? # true
table.description # Loads the full resource.
table.resource_partial? # false

returns.description: true when the table was created with a partial resource representation, false otherwise.

methods.name: resource_full?
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Table#resource_full?
methods.description: Whether the table was created with a full resource representation from the BigQuery service.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"

table.resource_full? # true

returns.description: true when the table was created with a full resource representation, false otherwise.
